LISP has a unique approach to immutability in functional programming. In LISP, all data structures are mutable by default. However, LISP provides programmers with the ability to create immutable values and data structures through a mechanism called "closures." 

Closures are objects that contain a reference to a value that cannot be changed once it is created. This allows LISP programmers to create immutable data structures that can be used in functional programming.

The impact of immutability in LISP has several benefits for software development. First, immutable data structures offer a higher level of safety and reliability in code. Since the data cannot be changed once it is created, it ensures that the data remains consistent throughout the program's execution, which reduces the likelihood of errors or unexpected behavior.

Furthermore, immutable data structures allow for better parallelism and concurrency in software development. Since data cannot be modified, multiple threads can safely access the same data structure without concern for potential conflicts or race conditions.

Lastly, immutability in LISP enables better performance optimization. By minimizing the amount of memory allocation and garbage collection, immutable data structures can improve application performance and reduce memory usage.

In summary, LISP handles immutability in functional programming through closures, which allows programmers to create immutable data structures. The impact of immutability in LISP includes improved safety, better parallelism and concurrency, and better performance optimization.
